> -----Original Message-----
> From: Dave Astels [mailto:dave@...] 
> Private methods support public methods.  Therefore well tested public 
> methods will include the behaviour of the private methods.  
> 
> There is no real reason for directly testing private methods.
> 

Domain objects support the GUI. By the logic above a well tested GUI
will include the behavior of the domain objects, so there is no reason
to unit test the domain objects :-)

I've occasionally found reason to write unit tests for private,
supporting methods. Often you loose efficiency testing supporting
methods indirectly via their caller - such as in the case where you want
to test their ability to properly handle a range of input values. 

Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather make
everything public and testable and expose real APIs via Java Interfaces.

To answer the original poster: google junit + "private methods"
